title: israel and united arab emirates strike historic peace accord
story: Senior White House officials Jared Kushner, Steve Mnuchin and  Robert O’Brien listen as US president Donald Trump announces the agreement between Israel and the UAE at the White House on Thurday. Photograph: Brendan SmialowskiAFP via Getty ImagesIsrael and the United Arab Emirates have reached a historic peace deal that will see the Gulf power normalising diplomatic relations with the Jewish state.The deal, brokered by the US, would mean the UAE will become only the third Arab state to have full diplomatic ties with Israel, after Egypt and Jordan. “HUGE breakthrough today! Historic Peace Agreement between our two GREAT friends, Israel and the United Arab Emirates!”, US president Donald Trump said on Twitter. The UAE, a staunch US ally, has been increasing its intelligence and security co-operation with Israel in recent years as both share common goals in countering Iran’s influence in the region and fighting Islamic extremism. Under Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed, Abu Dhabi’s crown prince and the UAE’s de facto leader, the Gulf state has pursued an increasingly assertive foreign policy across the Middle East that has barely disguised its burgeoning ties to Israel. The UAE move will be a significant victory for Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who regularly touts his success in improving Israel’s relations with Arab states that were once sworn enemies.As part of the deal, Israel has agreed to suspend annexing parts of the occupied West Bank. Mr Netanyahu had promised to annex areas of the Palestinian territory as he campaigned in elections last year, but the process stalled in recent weeks. – Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2020Read more about the Donald Trump administrationStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: kamala harris s policy vagueness could yet be a drawback
story: Kamala Harris: “Looking back, it is odd that such a fancied candidate did not do better in her own presidential campaign.”  Photograph: Carolyn KasterAPJoe Biden is not 77 in the way that Mick Jagger is 77. The Democratic candidate for the White House wears the years with a heaviness that is not lost even on his enthusiasts. While he never rules out a second term, this self-avowed “bridge” to the next generation implies just the one. With its lack of travel and live events, this Covid-19 election campaign, The Campaign That Isn’t, has spared him. The grandest public office in the world will not.Kamala Harris is, then, in line to be as much co-president as vice-president of the US. In the senator for California, Biden has hired not just a running mate but an executive burden-sharer and – forgive the macabre note – a viable stand-in. Given Biden’s taste for foreign affairs, she might have space to impose herself on the domestic realm in particular. Her potential influence is vast.It is also ambiguous. Biden has chosen Harris, yes, but which one? Disaffected Republicans will hope for the tenacious prosecutor with the Third Way patter. “It’s not progressive to be soft on crime,” she said, running for district attorney of San Francisco in 2003. As California’s attorney-general, she confronted the parents of truant children more zealously than she did the state’s draconian justice system.Progressives, for their part, will expect the other Harris. This is the one who opposed the death penalty earlier than many in her party and votes well to the left in the Senate. She was the untiring scourge of Republican nominees and witnesses in that chamber.There is no disgrace in inconsistency: give me an opportunist over an ideologue. Whether he actually said it or not, John Maynard Keynes’s airy line, “When the facts change, I change my mind”, is too stifling. People’s views can evolve even where the facts do not.It is just that Harris is such a pronounced case. A 55-year-old political lifer – she has never worked in the private sector – should have some definition by now. “Enigma” is the euphemism for someone whose core beliefs are so up in the air. Were she bidding to be a ceremonial vice-president, a less maladroit Dan Quayle, we need not worry. If elected, however, she is going to matter. And therefore so do her views.Presidential campaignLooking back, it is odd that such a fancied candidate did not do better in her own presidential campaign. She was a major politician from a state with a larger economy than that of most G20 countries (and all the donors that implies). She was of mixed race in a party that draws much of its support from minorities. Her Senate performances suggested not just ruthlessness but guile.In the end, what she did not have was perceived authenticity. In fact, every candidate in the Democratic primaries who had made a late-career turn to the left, namely senators Cory Booker and Kirsten Gillibrand, flopped. Voters preferred the real thing (Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren) or an unabashed moderate like the South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg. Policies mattered less than the conviction with which they were espoused.Biden ran some way to the left of his former self, but then he already commanded trust. Personal tragedy and almost 50 years in public life will do that. He had “earned” the right to stick a licked finger in the air and sense the wind’s direction.Of course, the national electorate is not the Democratic base. And had Biden named Warren or an untested mayor this week, President Donald Trump might be high-fiving campaign aides. The Biden-Harris pairing is far more daunting.Just not, in part thanks to that vagueness of hers, unbeatable. In a reptilian passage of Tony Blair’s chatty memoirs, the former UK prime minister explains how to go about negative campaigning. The classic error, he says, with the sureness of the thrice-elected, is the lurid, over-the-top attack. Swing voters learn to tune these out. What moves them is the lesser charge, expressed more in sorrow than in anger.UncertaintyTrump will never persuade Americans that Biden is a menace to the republic and “against God”. The criticism that might land is that he is too old and weak to run his presidency. Other forces will end up dominating. If one of them is a protean vice-president, a crime-hawk until she wasn’t, with changeable healthcare plans, the uncertainty is doubled. Caveat emptor.“Look, I like Joe,” a canny president might say. “But do you really know what you’re getting?” It would insinuate that Harris is an agent of the far left, but then blank canvases are there to be painted on. – Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2020Full coverage of the US presidential election 2020Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: a levels 2020 algorithms winners losers
story: This year's cohort of A-level students have been the first ever in England to open results letters with grades determined not by exams, but by an algorithm.With the coronavirus pandemic cancelling assessments, Ofqual, the authority that regulates qualifications, exams and tests in England, instead developed and deployed a statistical model to award students their grades.The process relied on schools sending on predicted grades to the regulator along with a ranking of students by performance, which were then standardised in light of past inidual achievement and the historic performance of the school. The result: just under 40 per cent of grades determined by teachers - termed formally by Ofqual as Centre Assessment Grades (CAGs) - have been downgraded by the model, with around 36 per cent downgraded by just one place and the rest dropping by two or more. Some students had exam results downgraded by three grades - 0.2 per cent of all entries.Read more: Almost 40 per cent of A-level results downgraded as Government under pressure to U-turnThese CAG downgrades has not been felt equally, however - poorer students in particular have been hardest hit, as was the case in Scotland earlier this month.Technical documents released by Ofqual shortly after results were first opened this morning show that, on average, a student from the lowest socio-economic groups saw their teacher's grades downgraded by 10.4 percentage points (pp).That compares to students of medium and high socio-economic groups, which saw downgrades of 9.5pp and 8.3pp respectively.Ahead of A-level results day Ofqual had claimed that, without lowering the predictions of teachers, grades this year would have risen by an average of 12 pp. To avoid that, the regulator stated it was aiming for a two pp rise in grade inflation instead.Indeed top marks are up this year - by 2.4pp, meaning the share of students receiving A*s or As is at its highest since at least 2001, at 27.6 per cent. But poorer students again have lost out when it comes to high grades  - Ofqual data also shows that though all socio-economic groups saw a rise in grades, those in higher groups saw an increase in the A* and As this year when compared to their share in 2019. Analysis of data from Ofqual has also found that the number of grades at A and above rose by 4.7 percentage points in private schools compared to last year - the highest of any type of institution.Sixth forms, further education and tertiary colleges saw the lowest shift of just 0.3 percentage points.Academies saw a rise of 1.7 points, while comprehensives and selective state schools all saw a rise of 2.0 and 1.2 respectively.Read more: A-Level results day - live updatesWhile grades rose from 2019 across the board, the rise was not evenly spread across the regions, with attainment highest in the south of the country.Students in the East Midlands and London saw a greater rise from the 2019 results in the proportion of entries achieving at least an A grade - up 3.4 percentage points in the East Midlands to 24.4 per cent, and up 2.9 percentage points in London to 29.8 per cent.The regions where most students achieved the top grades were the South East (30.7 per cent), London, (29.8 per cent) and the South West (28.6 per cent).The lowest attainment came in the Midlands, with 24.2 per cent of entries in the west and 24.4 per cent in the east achieving at least an A grade.Some heads have hit out at Ofqual's model for, they claim, penalising their bigger schools with systemic bias. We are deeply concerned that the adjustment process may have disadvantaged larger centres such as colleges and those with historically strong value added data, said David Hughes, the Chief Executive of the Association of Colleges.There seem to be inconsistencies across the board. While 39.1 per cent of Centre Assessment Grades were adjusted down by one or more grade overall, we are hearing from a number of colleges that over 50 per cent of their grades have been adjusted downwards.Colleges with large cohorts and very stable and predictable results over time are seeing their lowest grade profile ever, particularly at the higher grades, A to C. Because on average more disadvantaged students attend further education colleges this may have resulted in a systemic bias.It is for this reason that I have written to the Education Secretary and the Chief Regulator of Ofqual this morning to ask for an urgent technical review into the A Level results standardisation process. If colleges, and subsequently many disadvantaged students have been hit by an unfair or inconsistent process then this needs to be investigated immediately – and adjustments made quickly.This should not be left to inidual colleges or students having to use the appeals process.”In a letter released to universities across the country ahead of results day, Sally Collier, chief regulator at Ofqual, said relying on CAG results would have created unfairness between different schools and colleges. Data provided by Ofqual reveals the CAG system would have given some grades an uplift of more than 12pp on the previous year.A grades would have risen by 12.5pp and B grades by 13.8pp without the introduction of the algorithm.We tested our approach to standardising students’ grades extensively to ensure it would not advantage or disadvantage particular groups of students over others, said Ms Collier. We are reassured that our preliminary analysis of the data shows no widening of the attainment gap between students according to their backgrounds.She added she hoped universities would be flexible toward students who had missed out on a conditional offer due to downgrading.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ben jerrys wokeness irritating savvy firm right stand ground
story: In a world where tea brands are voices of reason and TV stars are presidents, why shouldn’t ice-cream makers chip in on immigration policy? That’s what happened this week, with Ben &amp Jerry’s and Priti Patel engaging in a war of words over migrants in dinghies crossing the English Channel.As is customary when a company raises its head above the parapet, Ben &amp Jerry’s soon found itself at the centre of a “Twitterstorm,”. The company’s mistreatment of migrant workers being one major bone of contention.Normally what happens when a company comes under fire is capitulation. The firm will rush out a statement about owning up to its mistakes, ignorance, and about how it will use this opportunity to listen and learn from those it has wronged. It will usually also allude to some form of structural prejudice at its core (sexism, racism, a dislike of the lactose intolerant) which it needs to address. It may, too, say it has sacked an employee or two, who it has deemed responsible (and expendable).Does anyone think Ben &amp Jerry’s is about to do any such thing? Of course not.Ben &amp Jerry’s is a junk food company that has decided to take on the British government just as Westminster contemplates restrictive bans on junk food advertising, not to mention a sugar tax. Moreover, it has decided to do so at the exact moment a heat wave has engulfed the country. It wants as much publicity at this point as it can get. But though Twitterstorms are largely seen as bad things, it has worked out this need not be.The phenomenon known as the Majority Illusion, where the amplifying of certain, well-connected voices on social media gives the impression of a view being more popular than it really is, is what allows many of these Twitterstorms to blow. Plenty of companies have folded on a position as a result, over the fear that a woke horde is descending across the digital steppe, when in fact just a few high-profile activists can create a whirlwind from waft. It also works in reverse — even if a majority of people are outraged over something, all it takes is for a similarly connected network to praise something (like, say, an ice cream company criticising a wicked, anti-migrant government) to amplify its message as the mainstream view.It’s not just through social media. Despite the majority of the nation being opposed to illegal immigration, that is not entirely true of those who control the channels through which news filters to the masses. For standing its ground, Ben &amp Jerry’s will continue to garner favourable coverage on this issue, rather than negative, for as long as it chooses to be vocal.What are those who disagree with that stance to do? Declare they’ll never buy the product again? We all know it would be a lie few of the people now haranguing Ben &amp Jerry’s seemed to have a moral issue over its exploitation of migrant labour. A tedious double insult ordinary people, who just want their borders properly policed and to be able to eat ice-cream in peace, could frankly do without. From a PR perspective, Ben &amp Jerry’s is right to stand its ground. It has more to gain from doing so than abandoning their position. What grates is that so many other companies that should stand theirs fail to, for fear of the online mob. How many people have been sacked, and how many firms have gone grovelling to a few outraged keyboard warriors, because of perceived injustice, hypocrisy or prejudice that didn’t really exist? We can all think of plenty of examples. Every time it happens, the majority feels a little more disheartened. It feels as though our prevailing view is less prevalent than we had thought, and we wonder what hope is left, as one by one, companies “go woke” to avoid going broke. It may sound counter-intuitive, but more need to do what Ben &amp Jerry’s have done, and stand their ground when the shadowy monsters come for them. The idea of monsters can terrify us into doing things we don’t want to, but we shouldn’t be scared of shadows. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: climate change rather overhunting may have caused woolly rhinos
story: Climate change rather than overhunting may have caused the woolly rhinoceros to become extinct around 14,000 years ago, scientists have said.The findings, published in the journal Current Biology, showed the megaherbivores' populations remained stable and erse for more than 13,000 years following the arrival of humans.Senior study author Love Dalen, a professor of evolutionary genetics at the Centre for Palaeogenetics, a joint venture between Stockholm University and the Swedish Museum of Natural History, said: It was initially thought that humans appeared in north-eastern Siberia 14,000 or 15,000 years ago, around when the woolly rhinoceros went extinct.But recently there have been several discoveries of much older human occupation sites, the most famous of which is around 30,000 years old.The researchers said this stability lasted until well after humans began living in Siberia, contrasting the declines that would be expected if the woolly rhinos went extinct due to hunting.Based on their findings, the scientists believe this species, which was particularly suited to the frigid north-east Siberian climate, may have declined due to the warming period towards the end of the last ice age.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: dithering britain denial eu turkey geopolitical time bomb
story: President Macron’s lightning visit to Lebanon after the Beirut explosion highlighted France’s increasingly active interventions around the Mediterranean. Yet few policymakers here seem to have taken on board the risk of a geopolitical explosion at sea between France and Turkey.The two estranged NATO allies are jousting for influence and energy resources from Libya to Cyprus. France is sending out warships and fighters as the war of words between President Macron and his Turkish bête noire, Recep Erdogan, intensifies.France is backing Greece and Cyprus with a show of force as Turkish warships escort a Turkish drilling ship into waters claimed by the two EU states. That Turkish exploration vessel is named in honour of the great Ottoman pirate and slaver, Oruc Reis, whose rampages ranged as far as the French coast from his Algerian base. The symbolism of its name is obvious. High summer ought to be holiday season around the Mediterranean but the buzzing of fighter jets increasingly disturbing.Our Foreign Office provides travel advisories for danger zones, but its advice about Greek islands in the frontline in sight of the Turkish coast is about the marginal risk of Covid-19 not war. If Whitehall had given travel advice in August 1914, it probably wouldn’t have noticed the unusually busy trains on German railways heading towards Belgium. Post-Brexit Britain has its own problems with France over cross-Channel illegal migration, but President Macron is showing how an independent foreign policy might look.Don’t let President Macron’s rhetoric about defending the European Union’s borders and sovereignty mislead you. The reality is that Greece and Cyprus are looking to France as a great power ally. The rest of the EU maybe good for a statement of support and even a threat of sanctions but when it comes to possible use of force only France counts. Paris has military power. Brussels has words. Britain still has two sovereign bases on Cyprus which is in the eye of the storm. Turkish troops still occupy the northern half of the island. Ankara remembers  the crisis of 1974 when Turkey intervened in Cyprus. Britain remained passive despite being a guarantor of Cyprus and its constitution.That was at the low point of our post-war decline. Yet today, Harold Wilson rather than Margaret Thatcher, let alone Winston Churchill, seems to be the guiding spirit of British policy towards the gathering storm in the Eastern Mediterranean. British expats and tourists in Cyprus might continue to enjoy a quiet life if the tensions lift, but there is little sign that London is alert to the risks to them and our military there.Nonchalance in a crisis can be an impressive pose, but the lassitude gripping British foreign policy this mid-summer is a symptom of a deeper confusion in Whitehall about what this country’s role should be around the world post-Brexit. It is not a conscious retreat to a “Little England” outlook. That would be a policy. Instead passivity seems a substitute for knowing what Britain wants and how it can achieve that. President Macron may be stretching France’s resources thin but he is purposeful.  More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: future china no longer playing nice rest world
story: Slimy, pungent stalls piled high with live animals in stacked cages. An unsanitary, untamed place with humans and wildlife packed in close quarters. The venue where a mystery virus can jump into the global population, creating devastating pandemics. The image of wet markets as disgusting and lawless – though a misperception – has already stuck. Calls have increased from around the world for China to shutter them to prevent a future outbreak. Such demands came after the coronavirus emerged at a seafood market in Wuhan, leading researchers to believe that a bug found in animals had mutated and jumped over to humans there.“I don’t think it’s necessary to close them – it’s a staple in daily life. But the sanitation regulations overall could be improved,” said Mrs Huang, 50, who has shopped at wet markets her whole life. Similar to what many in the West know as farmer’s markets, wet markets are typically rows of open-air stalls selling fresh meat, seafood, fruits and vegetables. They’re the place where many Chinese people visit to stock up on groceries. Some do sell and slaughter live animals, providing a fresh cut for the table. But exotic wildlife, like bats or civet cats, aren’t exactly common fare. Hu Tian, 30, is a fishmonger who peddled crabs and fish at the now-closed Wuhan market. He used to earn a living there to support his family of four. “I’ve sold goods in the market for more than 10 years, and I’ve never seen any bats,” he said. He now scrapes by via government subsidies.That’s not to say such animals aren’t being bred and traded. The Chinese government has pushed traditional remedies as part of a broader soft power campaign. Many of those herbal medicines use animal ingredients, such as bear bile, rhino horn and tiger bone. The rarer the remedy, the higher the price it sells for, an incentive for breeders to get in the game. Some looking to cut corners might engage in poor hygiene practices potentially dangerous to public health. As with many industries, regulating effectively is a challenge, even in an authoritarian state.Such nuance and distinction around China’s animal trade and its potential link to the Covid-19 pandemic has been completely lost as the world descended into emergency mode. A ergence in understanding about wet markets reflects a broader geopolitical ide that has occurred alongside the pandemic, with China and Western nations in many ways talking past each other. “Fracturing is a good word to describe where things are,” said Nadege Rolland, a senior fellow at the National Bureau of Asian Research. “I would argue that it started a while ago, and the fracture was already visible, but not as deep and probably, there was still hope that ‘we can do things together.’”“The last few months seem to have proven us otherwise,” she said. “This pandemic has accelerated this trend it served as a catalyst.” This puts the world in a dangerous place. Less engagement overall “is going to make the quality of understanding the other side much worse, and that’s going to lead to many more miscalculations,” said Martin Chorzempa, a research fellow who specialises in China at the Peterson Institute of International Economics. China’s handling of the pandemic – a heavy-handed response that included surveillance and suppression – made it clear to the world that the ruling Communist Party governed its country in a very different way to the West. On paper that had always been the case. But for many nations the coronavirus has highlighted the perils of dealing with an ever-powerful China driven by its own political motivations. It has prompted a rethink on engagement with Beijing, widening geopolitical fissures that were already in place. For years China seemed to accept that it had to play by rules set by the West in order to continue its rise. Now Beijing has indicated it wants to play by its own rules, and even have a say in setting them – brandishing its true colours in a way that can’t be ignored.Whether Beijing is successful in carving its own path – perhaps allowing other like-minded nations to follow suit – will shape global dynamics for years, perhaps decades, to come. As China grows ever more bold, the question is: Does Beijing even care what the West thinks any more?Before the pandemic, China was already at loggerheads with the US over trade. In Washington, there was talk of “decoupling” – essentially installing a firewall between the two countries as a way to protect America from the potential risk that came with the rise of China. Academics wondered whether the world was entering a “new Cold War.” None of this stopped Mrs Huang, part of China’s growing middle class, from saving funds to send her son, 20, to university in America to expose him to more ways of thinking. “In China, we look at issues from a single point of view, while in foreign countries, there are multiple perspectives taught,” she said. “To be a more open-minded person, you can’t just look at things your way.”Beijing was also embroiled in various diplomatic rows with countries including Australia, Canada and Sweden. In efforts to squeeze those nations, China acted boldly. Beijing arbitrarily detained two Canadians as retaliation after Ottawa arrested a Chinese tech executive during a layover in response to a US extradition request. There were mounting questions about the security threat of having Chinese companies involved in building key infrastructure, such as 5G mobile networks, or Chinese tech suppliers selling surveillance cameras and drones to national police forces. What would happen if the Chinese state compelled companies to give up data – a power inscribed in law? Then, pro-democracy protests roiling Hong Kong for months last year captured the world’s attention. Screens filled with images of riot police firing tear gas and rubber bullets at demonstrators fighting against Beijing’s encroaching control. The youngest person arrested was 11. Calls from the UK and US grew, urging China to employ a lighter touch. Beijing, tired of being scolded by the West, appeared to get more aggressive, not less. This was the backdrop against which the world entered the pandemic. In retrospect, it marked the beginning of a grinding decline that risks permanently souring China’s relations with the West.China has long had global impact, climbing quickly to become the world’s second-largest economy, powered by low-cost manufacturing and exports. At home, the Chinese watched their country transform from rice paddies and industrial wasteland into megacities – Shanghai and Beijing both have more than 20 million people. Mrs Huang, who declined to give her real name, talked of old Beijing, before small lanes disappeared into highways. The Costa Coffee branch we met in was located in a shiny mall towering over what used to be a patch of overgrown dirt. Like others in her generation, she lived through the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 when the Chinese military opened fire on peaceful pro-democracy student demonstrators – an incident the government still refuses to acknowledge. The bet the ruling Communist Party made was that the country of 1.4 billion people would accept less social and political freedoms in exchange for continued economic growth and upward mobility. At least so far, that gamble has proven right.“Our lives really did improve for the better,” said Mrs Huang. “There are two reasons we tolerate the way things are here – one, the standard of living is always advancing and second, from a young age, we were taught that things could only be this way.” Outside of China, many people likely felt it first in their wallets, enjoying lower retail prices as the country became the world’s factory of choice – cheap labour, fast production. Then, over the last decade, students from China began to fill more and more spots in universities around the world. Chinese investors snapped up prime assets – the Cheesegrater in London, the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York, Italian football club Inter Milan. Chinese shoppers, splashing their newfound wealth, boosted sales for luxury brands, like Louis Vuitton and Prada. But much of this was in the periphery, and didn’t touch the global population in a tangible way. That didn’t come until the coronavirus pandemic, when suddenly people encountered China in their living rooms.“It’s Covid that really stirred people up,” said Charles Parton, a former British diplomat who spent more than two decades working on greater China. The pandemic “brought the Chinese Communist Party into focus in people’s minds.”China’s cover-up and lack of transparency exacerbated the initial outbreak in Wuhan with unprecedented consequences. For weeks, Chinese authorities seeded complacency, telling the world there was no reason to worry. At the same time, whistleblowers – including doctors who noticed patients with strange illnesses – were detained, fined and reprimanded by police. Delays in reporting information occurred between the local and central government, and later, between Beijing and the world. Cases were discovered in other countries – Thailand, South Korea, Japan – for a full week before Chinese authorities admitted that human-to-human transmission was possible. Three days after announcing as such, the government locked down 11 million people in Wuhan. Hospitals didn’t have enough patient beds. Staff were so overwhelmed with coronavirus cases that pregnant women and cancer patients – even if they managed to obtain permission to travel during lockdowns – couldn’t get medical care.Evidence surfaced uncovering what appeared to be a far greater death rate than authorities had revealed. Pictures of corpses piled high circulated online briefly, before being deleted by government censors. But Beijing continued reassuring that all was under control. Early missteps were a direct consequence of how things run under the ruling Chinese Communist Party. And for the first time, repercussions due to the inner workings of the Party hit the world in a deeply personal way. The Party values stability above all, a characteristic leaders believe will allow them to stay in power, and avoid being dismantled, like the Soviet Union. What that translates to on the ground is an impulse to give the impression that everything is normal. Suppression of information is common – anyone challenging authority is squashed, and lower level cadres, whose promotions are linked to hitting at times impossible targets, are hesitant to report unsavory information up the chain.Chinese authorities would never allow anything to sully its image in the eyes of its people – fed a steady propaganda diet about how the Party, at the core of life, knows best. An educated class in China, like Mrs Huang – who works for a startup tech firm – is aware the authorities made mistakes, despite the government’s efforts to rewrite the narrative. She thinks they should be held accountable, but acknowledges there are no avenues to do so. What worries her more is that international backlash against the Party’s errors will spill over onto regular people like herself, and her son. “I really do think there were issues at the start of the pandemic, but the government is separate from the people,” said Mrs Huang. “I don’t know if regular Americans can avoid conflating the two.”Even in Wuhan, ground zero of the pandemic, people doubt the government’s version of events. “Ordinary people like us will never know the truth,” Long Menglei, 30, told me in April as lockdowns began lifting in the city. Her mother-in-law was severely ill with the virus for weeks. But it’s much easier to keep your head down, as government suppression never lets up.When infections began to fall and China crowed of containment success to the world, police continued to punish thousands of people for sharing information about the coronavirus online. Those trying to file lawsuits and seek reparations for deceased relatives have been harassed and intimidated by police, causing most to drop proceedings. Government control has extended into the afterlife, as grieving families haven’t been allowed to visit cemeteries.They may never be allowed to freely pay respects authorities still don’t allow families to remember those who died in the Tiananmen massacre, and from natural disasters, like the 2008 Sichuan earthquake – the ruling Party is always wary of groups gathering and griping about the government. It’s all so sensitive that a phalanx of police, minders and officials surrounded myself and a colleague when we visited a Wuhan cemetery to investigate, detaining and physically assaulting us, and harassing our driver. So it’s no surprise many feel resigned to whatever the government says is the truth. “I think we should believe the government,” said Mr Zhang, 40, a tech worker in Wuhan who was enjoying sunshine for the first time after 70 days indoors when we met. “There is no other possibility.” As the first country to discover infections, China was also the first to see cases subside.Authorities gloated about turning the corner and publicised a far-fetched origin story – that the US military had brought the coronavirus to China. Beijing was trying to deflect blame over its mishandling of the outbreak by redirecting public discontent toward stories of the country emerging victorious in what leader Xi Jinping called the “people’s war” against the coronavirus. Peddling this nationalist sentiment was an easy sell while the rest of the world remained in chaos. The government spied a chance to use global disruption to its advantage. “It is possible to turn the crisis into an opportunity – to increase the trust and the dependence on all countries around the world of ‘Made in China,’” said Han Jian, a director at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, a government think tank, in March. To that end, China began exporting medical materials and bragging about helping the world. Chinese state media conflated purchases of supplies by foreign nations with donated aid. “This boasting propaganda, which was of course aimed at the Chinese people although it’s conducted externally, enables them to say to the Chinese people, ‘Look at what we’re doing in the world China is leading the fight,’” said Mr Parton, now senior associate fellow at RUSI, a think tank.“This was, frankly, resented,” he said. “The Party is legitimising itself with its people, but at the same time, it mightily upsets the foreigners.” Some of the equipment that arrived was defective – inaccurate testing kits were sent to Spain, ventilators that couldn’t be sanitised properly were sold to the UK, and masks exported to the Netherlands didn’t meet required standards.Nations felt slighted, especially as many had sent supplies to China earlier in the year. Plus, global shortages existed partly because Beijing had hoarded equipment, instructing employees of state-owned enterprises to bulk-buy face masks and mail them home. There was little to be done – before the pandemic, China provided 40 per cent of the world’s imports of face shields, protective garments, gloves and goggles, according to PIIE. After ramping up production, China was making more than 100 million masks a day, 12 times more than prior to the outbreak. Countries that needed medical gear had no choice but to import from China.China had always trusted that such trade reliance meant countries would tread lightly but the pandemic highlighted the dangers of nations outsourcing key manufacturing to a country they couldn’t quite trust. This prompted deeper thinking on longstanding security concerns about Chinese involvement onshore in other areas.Halfway through 2020, the geopolitical ide is more evident than ever.The US and China are barreling down a rocky path. Relations have hit a new low after clashes over trade, technology, coronavirus, human rights concerns, Beijing’s territorial claims in the South China Sea, and its recent imposition of a draconian national security law in Hong Kong. The UK has reversed its decision on allowing Chinese telecoms firm Huawei a role in building the nation’s 5G networks over security concerns. London’s offer to allow three million Hong Kong people a pathway to British citizenship has further angered Beijing. Beijing is “very surprised by the outcome,” said Kitty Smyth, founder of Jingpinou, a UK consultancy specialising in China. “They’re genuinely shocked that Britain would choose to remain with a struggling America, rather than go forward with a rising China.” Even Switzerland – known for neutrality in its foreign policy – has asserted its stance. In early August, Swiss foreign minister Ignazio Cassis said that China’s “human rights violations are on the increase.”“We are seeing China stray from the path of openness,” he said. “This means that Switzerland, too, must defend its interests and values more robustly.”The Chinese “haven’t experienced pressure this intense from foreign governments for several years, if not decades,” said Ms Smyth. But China has steadily increased its swagger to defy the West, ramping up territorial disputes on land and at sea this year. In June, skirmishes broke out along the high-altitude border to India, leading to casualties. Chinese maritime activity has increased in the disputed South and East China Seas, where Beijing and many Southeast Asian countries lay claim to the resource-rich waters. China has also buzzed fighter jets over Taiwan, a democratically-governed island with its own military, currency, passport and foreign policy that Beijing considers a renegade province. Beijing has encouraged Chinese in Australia to return home, or at the very least remain vigilant, citing a rise in racism. The government has warned its people away from the US over discrimination. That swagger has also been deployed at home, with authorities crowing that invasive contact tracing tools contributed to containment success – justification for more draconian surveillance in what is already the world’s most intense digital police state.Facial recognition thermal checks and apps that track people’s movements are now the norm. Those under home quarantine have had cameras and sensors placed at their doors to ensure compliance. “This will absolutely continue,” said Mrs Huang. Surveillance and contact tracing apps “have been so successful, why would they stop using them?“I can’t do anything about it, and you can’t refuse to use them,” she said. “There’s no such thing as privacy here.” Such surveillance could quickly proliferate in countries with leaders who want to emulate China’s brand of authoritarian capitalism. China has also exported related technology around the world – facial recognition programs, surveillance cameras – including to the UK.More aggressive behaviour signals China is happy to disengage – at least with some of the world. Chinese ambassador to the UK Liu Xiaoming has threatened that Britain “will pay the price” after the Government reversed on Huawei. Chinese state media vowed “public and painful retaliation,” saying Beijing may not sit for post-Brexit trade talks. British businesses including HSBC, Burberry and Jaguar Land Rover have been named targets for consumer boycotts – a move that has before been hugely damaging for foreign brands amidst diplomatic spats.But “China is not going to become a hermit kingdom,” said Ms Rolland, who sees Beijing as “asserting its own influence, authority and power...over the non-Western and developing world, rather than Western, advanced industrial democracies.” The ide, she thinks, will fall along “a difference of systems and models that are based on very fundamentally different values.” The outlines of different bubbles of influence are emerging, especially as countries face off in the global vaccine race. The US and China have “pushed ethno-nationalist rhetoric toward science and technology as a way to boost national competitiveness, national interest,” said Yangyang Cheng, a particle physicist and postdoctoral fellow at Cornell University. China has long seen STEM fields as tools of national greatness, and pre-pandemic, was already investing significantly in these areas, including biomedicine and high-end medical devices. Plans are afoot to build 30 high-grade biosafety laboratories over the next five years.The coronavirus has bolstered China’s desire to grow stronger in science. Success could help Beijing deflect widespread anger over its cover-up of the pandemic, and buoy its coronavirus-ravaged economy. Beating the West in the vaccine race might even be the ultimate sign that China has become so self-sufficient that it no longer needs to play nice with the US and the UK. It would also arm China with a tool to exert greater influence – a way to build diplomatic ties. Indeed Beijing has vowed “to give priority” to the Philippines if it develops a vaccine. Canada, on the other hand, is still waiting for vaccine doses to arrive from China after agreeing to partner in clinical trials the shipment remains stalled in customs.From a public health perspective, looking at vaccines as a way to profit is “to the collective detriment of our species,” said Ms Cheng. “That is a dangerous and really unfortunate attitude, because vaccine development and biomedical research in general should not be seen as a race,” she said. “Whatever is developed should be a public good it shouldn’t be something incentivised by financial interest or geopolitical calculations.” In China, propaganda and patriotic education are in overdrive, painting the West as the enemy. The sense is: “It’s really a hostile world out there, and we – as in the Chinese people – have to rely on ourselves,” said Ms Cheng. That nationalist sentiment resonates with most Chinese, who are proud to hail from a country that has, in their eyes, overcome all odds to yet again become a world leader – despite having been humiliated in the past by foreign powers.Beijing, tired of kowtowing to the West, is now puffing its chest with a new “wolf warrior” style of diplomacy – referring to a series of patriotic action films where the hero defends Chinese interests at home and abroad. But the idea that China and its people must band together to do battle with the enemy West hasn’t necessarily worked on everyone. Chinese with higher socioeconomic standing, like Mrs Huang, are often far more likely to believe the government is moving backwards. She admires the West’s democratic freedoms, and shakes her head disapprovingly when asked to assess the government’s virus response and whether she thinks leader Xi is taking the country in the right direction. But surveillance and suppression of dissent is so common that she doesn’t dare say his name out loud.Her family is considering immigrating to the US, though she worries whether they’d fit in as geopolitical fissures widen: “I wonder, would Americans still welcome me?”Experts hope the cracks appearing between China and the West will be temporary. Beijing has indicated interest in continuing to work together, though on its own terms. “It’s really tragic...this pandemic should have made people less narrow-minded, less nationalistic, because what it has taught us is that nations and human bodies are all porous entities,” said Ms Cheng. Determining and agreeing to new rules of engagement will be difficult. Mid-sized countries, like the UK, are “trying to find their own path in dealing with that overarching rivalry between the US and China, between these two,” said Ms Rolland. “It’s going to get a lot more complicated with European countries, because their whole model rests on the same basis and fundamental values as the Americans, rather than China.”“The worst case scenario is not a cold war,” said Mr Chorzempa. “It’s something much worse, much more confrontational.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: israel normalise relations uae historic deal
story: Donald Trump, the US president, said on Thursday that the United Arab Emirates and Israel have agreed to establish full diplomatic ties as part of a deal to halt the annexation of occupied land sought by the Palestinians for their future state.The announcement makes the UAE the first Gulf Arab state to do so and only the third Arab nation to have active diplomatic ties to Israel.Trump tweeted a statement from the countries, acknowledging the deal. He then told reporters in the Oval Office that it was a truly historic moment.Now that the ice has been broken I expect more Arab and Muslim countries will follow the United Arab Emirates, he said.The recognition grants a rare diplomatic win to Trump ahead of the November election as his efforts to see an end to the war in Afghanistan have yet to come to fruition while efforts to bring peace between Israel and the Palestinians have made no headway.For Israel, the announcement comes after years of boasting by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that his government enjoys closer ties to Arab nations than publicly acknowledged.Mr Netanyahu has sought to build settlements on lands sought by the Palestinians and embraced a Trump proposal that would allow him to annex large parts of the occupied West Bank while granting Palestinians limited autonomy in other areas.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: level results day grades contest mock exam ucas university clearing
story: Close to 40 per cent of A-level grades were downgraded, figures show, amid calls for the Government to U-turn on its grading system.A total of 39.1 per cent of grades in England were lowered from teachers' predictions, data from exam regulator Ofqual revealed (the graph below shows the breakdown).The majority of grades, 35.6 per cent, were lowered by one grade, while 3.3 per cent were pulled down by two and 0.2 per cent were bought down by three.This year, 27.6 per cent of A-levels were graded as A or A*, a 2.4 increase on last year and the highest proportion of top grades since 2001.But, as pupils around the country received their A-level results, the Government faced growing calls to abandon its grading system, largely based on using a statistical model as well as a rank order drawn up by teachers.Geoff Barton, the general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said that while there has been an overall increase in top grades, headteachers were very concerned that this disguises a great deal of volatility among the results at school and student level.He said: We have received heartbreaking feedback from school leaders about grades being pulled down in a way that they feel to be utterly unfair and unfathomable. They are extremely concerned about the detrimental impact on their students.We are now calling on the Government and the exam regulator Ofqual to review the situation as a matter of urgency, and we would warn them against simply digging in their heels and insisting all is well.The Sixth Form Colleges Association said: The process for calculating this year's A-level results appears to have fundamentally failed, based on our survey of sixth form colleges. The association said the Government and Ofqual must now revert to teacher-assessed grades.Read more: A-level results day 2020 - live updatesThis year's grades have been calculated by a statistical model, which took into account various factors including pupils' past performance as well as their school's historic grades, combined with the rank order drawn up by teachers.Ofqual came up with model to calculate grades and teachers were asked to put students in a rank order of best to worst.Earlier this week, Gavin Williamson, the Education Secretary, apologised for the disruption students have faced but refused to back down over the use of an algorithm to calculate A-level results.Mr Williamson said that, if teachers' predictions were awarded to pupils unaltered, grades would shoot up and the qualifications would be devalued.On Wednesday evening, he made an 11th hour change to the system which meant pupils could now appeal against their grade on the basis of their mock exam results.It was the latest in a series of last-minute changes to the appeals system ahead of results day and followed a major U-turn by the Scottish Government which threw Whitehall into a panic about how to head off a similar crisis.John Swinney, the Scottish education minister, announced on Tuesday that the 124,564 grades that had been downgraded by the Scottish algorithm would be withdrawn and replaced with teachers' recommendations.The Welsh education minister, Kirsty Williams, pledged to introduce a safety net meaning students would not get a lower A-level grade than their AS mark.Unlike in England, where AS levels were axed under a series of reforms to toughen up A-levels, they remain in place in Wales, meaning they can be relied on as an indicator of a pupil's performance in exam conditions.Read more: A-level results day guide to clearing, grades and next stepsMr Williamson gave his assurance on Thursday that he will not make the same exam grades U-turn seen in Scotland.What is clear to me is there will be some youngsters, no matter how much we try to do in terms of this system to maximise the fairness of it, who don't get the grade they should have potentially have got, he said.That's why we need to have a really robust system, that's why we've got the triple lock.Mr Williamson said this would provide robust grounds of appeal and allow pupils to take exams later in the year if required.But despite claims that Ofqual has no system in place for assessing the validity of mock exam results, the Education Secretary said there was a whole range of routes that schools can take the appeal process through, adding that the mock exam was an important step forward to ensure there's enhanced fairness for all pupils right across England.He said more information about appeals would be released to schools and colleges over the next few days.Languages and mathematics saw the highest proportion receiving the top grades (see graphic below) amid a fall in the total number of entries sitting.Two thirds (66.1 per cent) of those sitting modern languages other than French, Spanish and German received either A* or A, up 15 percentage points on last year.For further mathematics it was 61.8 per cent, up 8.3 percentage points on last year.Some of the subjects receiving lowest proportion of the coveted top grades (see graphic below) were English language (11.4 per cent), media, film and TV studies (13.8 per cent) and business studies (15.2 per cent).The 2019 A-Level cohort saw the proportion of entries among girls sitting the three main science subjects – biology, chemistry and physics – overtake boys for the first time since 2011.That trend has continued, with the gap between the genders widening in 2020 (see graphic below).The proportion of entries into the sciences among girls rose from 50.3 per cent in 2019 to 50.9 per cent this year. But overall entries into sciences mirror the wider trend, with falling numbers of entries across the board.Around 10,000 fewer entries were made among girls in 2020 across the sciences among girls from the previous year, and 11,000 fewer entries among boys.More girls are sitting biology (38,067 entries among girls vs 21,406 among boys) and chemistry (28,120 vs 23,730 boys), but more boys are still sitting exams in physics (7,997 girls vs 26,999 boys).But girls achieved higher grades than boys in physics, with 33.7 per cent achieving A* and A, versus 29.8 per cent among boys.Girls also performed better in biology (25.3 per cent achieving the top grades vs 23.7 per cent for boys), but boys did best in chemistry (32.1 per cent for boys vs 28.9 per cent for girls).Overall, girls made up 55.4 per cent of all A-Level entries in 2020, up from 55 per cent in 2019 and 2018.It has been the best year for attainment among both boys and girls, with the former achieving 27.1 per cent A* and A (up 1.9pp on 25.2 per cent in 2019) and the latter achieving 28 per cent A and A* (up 2.9pp from 25.1 per cent in 2019). More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: nicola sturgeon has put populism ahead fairness exam grade free
story: The dramatic announcement on Tuesday in Scotland over students’ exam results, allowing teaching assessments to stand as students’ final grades, is riven with public emotion.While Gavin Williamson offered a compromise deal in England, allowing students to use their mock results if higher than their actual outcomes, the Government has steadfastly avoided political short-termist thinking, refusing to follow Scotland’s lead where sensible standardisation measures have been thrown out of the window in favour of political opportunism.Nicola Sturgeon’s U-turn is populism at its worst, flying in the face of fairness – the holy grail that exam regulators have been attempting to pin down this year in the absence of exams due to the coronavirus pandemic.England’s approach is a complicated model comparing a prioritised list of student outcomes, with multiple avenues of appeal and comparison against their school’s previous results. It attempts to maintain standards and so protect the currency of qualifications, rather than allow rampant grade inflation which serves no one.This is by no means ideal, but – to borrow a Churchillian turn of phrase – it is only the worst way of delivering students' results except for all the others. Among those clamouring for a similar change of heart in England as in Scotland, the argument goes something like this: results on a national level aren’t important, as league tables and accountability for schools have been suspended this year, while inidual results have a significant impact on a young person’s future forever. Teacher assessments should therefore stand, regardless of whether they would have seen results leap by 12 percentage points.But surely, if the argument is that inidual results should take precedence over any attempt to standardise, then all children should be given an A* at A-level or grade 9 at GCSE. All kids would then get perfect results and therefore equal access to universities, apprenticeships or employment in the future.Yet giving everyone A*s and 9s would help no-one. Both the Scottish Qualifications Authority (SQA) and Ofqual, England’s regulator, knew this months ago and as a result had spent that time building standardisation models that were tested within an inch of their lives to make the process as fair as possible.Centre assessed grades are the heart of the row in Scotland. In laymen’s terms this means predicted grades – teachers forecasting the results of their students before taking an exam.In England these are still used as part of a young person’s application to a university – something that is quite unique internationally. But research has shown that in university applications only 16 per cent of applicants were correctly predicted their A-Level outcomes – clearly putting into question the reliability of this model.All the research points to the fact that teachers are over-generous in their grading, but when compared with national benchmarks, there are also significant concerns that students from black and minority ethnic backgrounds are likely to be under-predicted. This is conscious or unconscious bias in action.Much of the national debate this week has focused on how fair the results were for those Scottish students who were downgraded. No system is fair – which is just as true for basing grades entirely on teacher predictions. It is unfair to students whose teachers did not try to game the system but worked within the boundaries the Scottish government laid out. Compare the school that decided tactically to give the top grades to as many students as possible, regardless of performance, with the school that diligently worked through what grades students truly deserved.Think of the agonising that teachers themselves will now be going through, going over in their minds every grade they allocated and every decision they made. And of course, it is also unfair to all students in Scotland whose grades now, in Nicola Sturgeon’s own words, have no credibility. Most of all, it is unfair on those kids for whom their results mean they won’t get into a university in England because they are competing against English students, where the overall system to grade students this year carries weight. Consider those that do get into the university of their choice but find that they are unable to engage with the content because they missed out on vital teaching in core subjects. And spare a thought too for those who will go through interview processes to get their first job – up against others with exam results from 2019 or 2021 – and who won’t get the position because the employer can’t trust in their results.It is clearly not possible to judge with 100 per cent accuracy which pupil would have passed or failed based on their skills and knowledge in any system that does not have standardised testing. And there is still more to do to ensure fairness in England, particularly waiving appeal fees for students unhappy with their grades.But by holding firm on Ofqual’s standardisation, the UK Government has prioritised children’s futures over populism.  They have protected a young person’s results for life from knee-jerk, politically charged decisions – exactly like the one taken by John Swinney and Nicola Sturgeon on Tuesday.All in all, political expediency must not trump what is right and what it genuinely fair – not just to this year’s students, but students past and future too.Unity Howard is director of the New Schools NetworkMore from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: oldham brink full lockdown coronavirus cases surge
story: Katrina Stephens, the director of public health for Oldham Council, said a full lockdown could take place in days rather than weeks unless people adhered to rules.Mr Burnham said a full lockdown should only be considered when everything else has been tried first, adding: To go from where we are today to full lockdown, that would present serious difficulties for the public but also for Greater Manchester services as well.He confirmed he had written to Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, alongside the Manchester City Council leader, Sir Richard Leese, to set out his concerns.Speaking during a weekly press briefing, he said: We need to see the pubs, particularly, implementing the measures, capturing people's names and addresses, so we can then make sure that the test and trace system is working as well as it should do.He also said he would be writing to the major supermarkets to call for a stricter approach to enforcing the wearing of face coverings in stores.There have been 70 confirmed cases in the region in the past week, and council leader Jonathan Nunn said the situation could go either way.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: uk recession economy gdp coronavirus lockdown
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Country posts worst quarterly fall in GDP on record during coronavirus lockdown&nbsp– but shows signs of recovery in JuneThe UK plunged into its deepest recession on record in the first half of the year as the coronavirus lockdown saw the economy contract by more than a fifth between April and June.The economy shrank by 20.4 per cent in the second quarter of the year, worse than any other G7 nation, taking the UK into its first recession since the 2008-2009 financial crisis.The dramatic fall in output came after a 2.2 per cent drop in the first three months of the year.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA recession is defined as two successive quarters of decline in GDP. The US and eurozone have both already been confirmed as being in recession.There were signs of a recovery beginning, as monthly gross domestic product (GDP) rose by 8.7 per cent in June but is 17.2 per cent below February 2020 levels, the Office for National Statistics said.Britain faces up to the prospect of mass unemploymentSurvey results showed that businesses are increasing output as demand has risen following the easing of social distancing and lockdown measures.Manufacturing, construction and services all experienced widespread growth in June as businesses were allowed to resume trading, but output in all three sectors remained significantly below pre-pandemic levels.The output of service industries remains 17.6 per cent below the level of February, after growing by 7.7 per cent in June.Manufacturing remains 14.2 per cent below February levels after growing by 11 per cent since May.Construction saw the biggest fall in output and the sharpest rebound. It expanded 23.5 per cent in June as sites reopened but output is 24.8 per cent down on February levels.Some services sectors continue to be more severely affected as many businesses remain closed, the ONS said. Among the biggest declines were in the food and beverage services industry where output was barely a quarter of pre-lockdown levels in June. Government ministers and economists will be closely watching the data for signs that any recovery continued to gain momentum in July and August as pubs, restaurants, bars and hairdressers, among other businesses, were allowed to reopen.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailUK to formally enter recession as chancellor prepares for budget delayRecession less severe than feared but unemployment to surge, says BoEWhat lessons can we draw from the eurozone’s coronavirus recession?Consumer spending plummeted by a record 23.1 per cent in the second quarter of the year. While that was largely expected as broad sections of the economy shut down, it remains to be seen how quickly people will have returned to their old spending habits in recent weeks.  Jonathan Athow, deputy national statistician at the ONS, said: “The recession brought on by the coronavirus pandemic has led to the biggest fall in quarterly GDP on record.“The economy began to bounce back in June with shops reopening, factories beginning to ramp up production and housebuilding continuing to recover.“Despite this, GDP in June still remains a sixth below its level in February, before the virus struck.“Overall, productivity saw its largest-ever fall in the second quarter. Hospitality was worst hit, with productivity in that industry falling by three-quarters in recent months.”Economists forecast that, although the coronavirus recession is unprecedentedly deep, it should be of short duration.“While the UK recession involved a record contraction, it should at least be limited to two quarters,” said Howard Archer, chief economist of the EY Item Club. “The economy has been growing at an increasing rate since May and it appeared to take a further step forward in July as lockdown restrictions were eased further.“The substantial fiscal and monetary stimulus that has been enacted should provide ongoing support to the economy.”He added: “There should also be some pent-up demand following the overall reduction in consumer spending in the second quarter, while household purchasing power is being helped by very low inflation. Global economic activity is also now improving as other economies recover from the impact of coronavirus. This will help UK exports.”Moving out of the technical recession does not mean that the economic pain is over, however. Businesses hit hard by the pandemic are expected to lay off large numbers of staff over the coming months as support measures such as the furlough scheme come to an end.Chancellor Rishi Sunak said that the ONS figures “confirm that hard times are here”.“Hundreds of thousands of people have already lost their jobs, and sadly in the coming months many more will.“But while there are difficult choices to be made ahead, we will get through this, and I can assure people that nobody will be left without hope or opportunity.”Official data showed this week that around 730,000 UK workers have been removed from the payrolls of British companies since March when the coronavirus lockdown began.The number of hours worked each week plunged by a fifth and 7.5 million people were temporarily absent from work in July.The Bank of England forecast last week that the economy will shrink by 9.5 per cent in 2020 after a rebound in the second half of the year as restrictions ease and activity gears up again.It upgraded its forecast after energy usage and travel data suggested a faster pick-up than had been predicted. title: jurassic park goof raptor scene mistake world dominion spielberg
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Blunder occurs during the climactic velociraptor sceneAn eagle-eyed fan has noticed a blunder in the beloved 1993 movie Jurassic Park, 27 years after the film’s release.The error comes in the famous scene when velociraptors hunt down Lex (Ariana Richards) and Tim (Joseph Mazzello) in one of the park’s kitchens.Posting on the MovieDetails Reddit sub-forum, the viewer wrote: “In Jurassic Park, there is a scene where the raptor opens the door to the kitchen and you can spot an operator grab the raptor’s tail.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIn the film, the dinosaurs were created through a mixture of CGI and puppetry. Just as the Reddit user described, it is indeed possible to glimpse an operator’s hand just as the shot is panning away from the raptor.While other Reddit users expressed surprise at the discovery, errors like this are common in films. IMDb has identified 341 goofs in Jurassic Park, many of which are to do with continuity. Sam Neill: ‘Science was neglected, and that’s biting us on the arse’Jurassic Park actor Sam Neill says new film is ‘best yet’Certain errors in major films have become infamous over the years, such as the appearance of a white van during a battle scene in Braveheart, or the presence of bullet holes in a scene in Pulp Fiction before guns have been fired.In another Jurassic Park scene, the untrustworthy Dennis Nedry (Wayne Knight) is seen talking to someone by “video link”, but viewers are able to clearly discern that he is simply watching a pre-recorded video.The lead stars of Jurassic Park – Sam Neill, Jeff Goldblum and Laura Dern – are set to reprise their roles in the upcoming Jurassic World: Dominion, which recently resumed filming, having been suspended due to the coronavirus pandemic.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: mission impossible 7 tom cruise stunt accident set motorbike release date
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Production had just got back up and runningMission: Impossible 7 is said to have been hit by yet another delay after a motorbike stunt went dangerously wrong.The vehicle was supposed to safely land on a platform of pillows filled with cardboard after a particular sequence.However, due to the heat and the friction of the tyres, it caught alight, which reportedly forced the stuntman to jump clear.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAccording to The Sun, Tom Cruise – the film’s lead star and producer – was working on another stunt elsewhere.Set photos show black smoke around the area where the stunt took place. Reports say that Oxfordshire Fire Service put the fire out and that nobody was injured.The costly stunt is thought to have been six weeks in the making, with a source admitting: “Unfortunately, it was miscalculated.”Subtitles for ‘inaudible’ Avengers scene may reference X-Men characterIs Tenet a sequel to Inception? Farfetched theory explainedTimothy Dalton: ‘Why do we need to offer people gratuitous sex?’They continued: “The heat and the friction of the tyres meant that when the bike crashed, the cardboard padding sparked and went up in flames.”According to reports, Cruise is “frustrated” by the delay, with the inside calling the situation “a catastrophe”.The Independent has contacted Paramount Pictures for comment.Earlier this month, the sequel – which is being directed by Christopher McQuarrie – found itself in deep water after it was reported the film’s crew is pushing to blow up a bridge in Poland that is considered a national monument by locals.Part of the disused bridge, which is situated in the village of Pilchowice, would be detonated for the stunt.However, crew members are facing obstruction from local citizens despite Deputy Culture Minister Pawel Lewandowsk claiming that the bridge has no cultural value.Production on Mission: Impossible 7, which will be directed by Christopher McQuarrie, is set to resume in the UK in September, before heading to Poland in April.The film will be released in November 2022.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: twilight saga stephenie meyer midnight sun new book sequel when
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.One chapter is already written, but fans should expect to wait for a whileStephanie Meyer has said that she plans to write at least two more books in her hit Twilight vampire series.The revelation arrives as the latest entry, Midnight Sun, has topped the bestsellers charts in both sides of the Atlantic.During an online event for US books chain Books-A-Million, the author said (per USA Today): “There are two more books I think in the world that I want to write. I have got them outlined and a chapter written I think of the first one, so I know it’s there.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHowever, it could be a while before fans will be able to get their hands on the next Twilight instalments. Meyer added: “I am not ready to do that right now – I want to do something brand new.”The Twilight saga was also adapted into a hit film franchise, which starred Robert Pattinson as the sullen vampire Edward and Kristen Stewart as the love-struck mortal Bella.Midnight Sun review: Time’s up for Twilight’s twisted romanceAnna Kendrick compares working on Twilight to a ‘hostage situation’Midnight Sun has sold more than a million copies in the US in a week.In the UK, 62,460 hardback copies  were sold in the three-day window between the novel’s launch and the cut-off date for sales monitor Nielsen BookScan’s charts, which was enough to launch Meyer into the number one spot. In a two-star review for The Independent, Annie Lord wrote that Midnight Sun is “a frustrating reminder of how much of popular culture focuses on a helpless woman being saved by a troubled, yet ultimately forgivable man”.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: ae weiwei help the hungry campaign auction tracey emin sotherbys
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Sotheby’s sale raising&nbspfunds for food surplus charity The Felix Project will also feature&nbspwork by Tracey&nbspEmin,&nbspBridget Riley&nbspand&nbspAnish&nbspKapoorArtworks by Ai Weiwei, Tracey Emin and Anish Kapoor are among those to be featured in a Sotheby’s contemporary art auction next week to support The Independent’s Help The Hungry campaign.The sale, part of Sotheby’s Contemporary Art Day Auction that runs from 20 to 30 July, includes leading contemporary artists Bridget Riley, Mark Wallinger and Bob and Roberta Smith. All money raised from the auction will go to The Independent’s appeal partner, The Felix Project, London’s largest food surplus distribution charity. Our campaign has so far raised £7.5m towards our £10m goal which includes a pledge to open London’s largest community kitchen to tackle food poverty.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHighlights from the Sotheby’s Help the Hungry auction include a drawing from Tracey Emin, a series of three etchings by Anish Kapoor, Mark Wallinger’s “Ghost”, and Bob &amp Roberta Smith’s “We Have Only Got Each Other” placard.British-Nigerian artist Yinka Shonibare also joins the catalogue with his “Unstructured Icons - Aristocrat I” alongside a pair of polished steel reliefs by Michael Craig-Martin and a floral plate by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.   How to support our campaignSotheby’s senior director Oliver Barker said: “We are grateful to the artists who have generously contributed their works and we’re looking forward to channelling part of the excitement of our major sales in London this month into a cause which will provide food and comfort to the capital’s most vulnerable.”  Evgeny Lebedev, proprietor of The Independent, said: “We are delighted to be raising money with Sotheby’s and some of the world’s leading contemporary artists to help build London’s biggest community kitchen that will continue to feed those in need for years to come.”The Felix Project distributes nutritious food that would otherwise go to waste to 350 frontline charities, schools and holiday programmes in London.Founder Justin Byam Shaw said: “Although our food is surplus and donated to us and we have over 1,500 volunteers, our costs are still spiralling. “The coming unemployment crisis means we are in this for the long term. This new community kitchen will provide a high-quality meal for homeless Londoners, cooked by great chefs using surplus food.” Turner Prize-winning artist Mark Wallinger said: “I am delighted to contribute to help raise funds for The Felix Project, a fantastic charity that does such vital work in providing food for vulnerable people throughout London, work that is ever more necessary in our current crisis.”Sotheby’s Help The Hungry Auction will go live on 20 July and will run until 30 July.Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Several new hotspots appear to be emerging in areas throughout the countryCoronavirus cases are once again on the rise in the UK, climbing to their highest level since late June.Daily new cases reached above 900 this week, having briefly fallen below 500 in July, with several areas experiencing large spikes in infections.The outbreaks prompted the government to reintroduce restrictions in Greater Manchester, east Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire in late July.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe latest figures from Public Health England reveal that several other areas around the country are also seeing a surge in new cases, according to The Independent‘s analysis.Swindon has seen 55 new Covid-19 cases per 100,000 inhabitants over the last seven days – more than some areas where containment measures are currently in place. Swindon is now the fourth worst affected area in the UK when measured as a proportion of population, having seen a 200 per cent increase in new cases over the last seven days.It has nearly as many new cases per person as Leicester, which was the first place to see tougher local restrictions put in place after the nationwide lockdown lifted.The UK as a whole remains a long way off its peak levels from April and May, when daily new cases frequently reached above 5,000.Yet local spikes could see the recent upwards trend continue if not brought under control, as has been the case in other countries like France and Spain.Having endured a big surge in cases during the early stages of the pandemic, London has since seen its number of daily cases drop at an even greater rate than the rest of the country.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists.
